reviewText: An interesting and failry creepy game for a "Rail Shooter". I say rail shooter because the game path is pretty narrow. Forget side trips, looking for anything special or worrying about taking wrong turns.The story is about a meteorologist in the Arctic trying to reach a ship for his return home.Upon finding the ship it appears wrecked and you explore the ship and witness a chain of events leading up to the disaster. Some how you are able to interact with past events as you try to prevent the catastrophe. Weird, mutated humans will attack and you will witness ghosts in their last few minutes of life. During your adventure you will be moving from past to present and back with the ability to change some of the events or accidents that befall ship and crew. How? I don't know. I am still not sure whether you, the ship or both are ghosts.The game is little too linear but overall enjoyable as you became accustomed to the restrictive gameplay.Unfortunately the game is a little short since there is little exploration required; figure about 15 hours for most gamers. Weapons from pieces of metal to rifles will be found throughout. Health will be collected in the form of heat from various items such as light bulbs and steam pipes. (neat concept). Game physics are somewhat annoying. Sometimes you can jump 4 feet high and another time you can't jump over a chair. Also, your weapons feel like they're made of rubber with a weight tied to the end. The graphics look pretty good but you may experience slow downs on the higher video settings. Even "Crysis" gives me better frame rates. This is the only game in a long time that has a sub 40 fps on my system.Overall:Graphics are good but the engine needs optimizing...... 6/10Sound is very good with lots of creepy creaking........ 9/10Voice acting is OK but words are frequently misspoken.. 7/10Game physics is a little frustrating................... 6/10The story line is interesting but confusing............ 6/10Minor bugs............................................. 9/10It's fun enough to recommend........................... 7/10

summary: An outstanding story-driven game in a fascinating world
reviewText: Ken Levine and his team at Irrational Games have been making some of the most important video games in existence for over a decade. Very few developers are in their league when it comes to crafting virtual world we want to live and play in, and Bioshock Infinite just might be their crowning achievement in this regard. The floating world of Columbia, with its extreme, far-right idealism and frightening inhabitants, makes for one of the most intriguing settings ever seen in any video game. Wrapped together with a strong story that truly becomes mind-blowing towards the end, and Bioshock Infinite is easily one of the defining moments of the seventh generation of console gaming. Releasing near the end of the PS360 era, it serves as a summation of what made this generation's AAA games so unique...memorable, immersive experiences taking place in incredible virtual worlds.Bioshock Infinite's story cannot be discussed in detail without revealing too much. Safe to say that while it seemingly begins down one track, exploring the dark side of American idealism gone horribly wrong, it soon morphs into something completely different. Like the original Bioshock, the game can be horrifying and shocking at times, but it also has moments of beauty that are unsurpassed. Many of these moments are due to your companion throughout the game, Elizabeth, perhaps the most masterfully constructed AI companion to ever appear in a video game. Her innocence, strength, mysterious nature, and audacity lend an emotional weight to the game that is quite engaging. Unlike many other AI companions, she not only takes care of herself, but is also extremely useful during combat scenarios, becoming a huge aide in your quest to discover the truth about what is happening in Columbia.Unfortunately, much like the first Bioshock, combat isn't always the magical experience that exploring Columbia is. It gets rough at spots, with somewhat awkward shooting mechanics, "powers" that aren't entirely satisfying, and an opportunity to fight from great heights and speeds thanks to the network of "skylines" that connect the various sections of Columbia, an interesting idea that is much more fun in theory than in its execution. Thankfully, the combat is serviceable most of the time, but the combat gameplay never quite reaches the level of some of the finer first person experiences provided to us by the PS360 era. But with Bioshock Infinite, this hardly matters. This is a game where the game world is the star of show. Around every corner of Columbia, there is something fascinating to see, to hear, or to take. It is a dense game world crafted from brilliant, creative minds, and offers some of the most incredible sights and sounds you'll find in any video game. This is a game to be savored. You'll want to stop and smell the roses at every opportunity you can, as doing so is fulfilling and rewarding in a way few games are.Despite its few shortcomings, Bioshock Infinite is a masterpiece, through and through. Endlessly fascinating, thrilling, and compelling, games like this don't come around very often. Do not miss it.

description: Warner Bros. Batman: Arkham Origins 1000381344 PC Games
summary: So close to excellent, and yet with miles to go
reviewText: DISCLAIMER:  I've fully played this game on both the PS3 and the PC.  PC specs below.The short version:As a fan of both Arkham Asylum and Arkham City, I would have been perfectly happy with 'more of the same', and in many ways that's what we get in Arkham Origins.  Most of the game only slightly expands upon the previous two entries.Unfortunately, here we are 6 months later and its biggest detriment is still the bugs--not just annoying glitches but real show-stoppers.  If these could be ironed out, we'd have a 5-star entry in the series that lacks only a bit in the area of storyline and 'new ideas'.  The bugs I report here I have encountered on both the PC and the PS3, and as recently as last week (February 2014).The details:Arkham Origins tells us the story of Gotham City prior to the Arkham Asylum and Arkham City storylines.  What makes the story so wonderful is not only some excellent writing that really digs into the depth of Batman and the Joker, and reaches into the mob families that flesh out Batman's world in works like 'The Long Halloween' and 'Dark Victory'...but we also gain insights into a ton of hanging story ideas that were there in Arkham City, making the entire arc of these games seamless.  In Arkham City, you have clues that talk about Black Mask and he's never in the game--why?  Because we get his story here.  Why did Penguin refer in Arkham City to something Batman did to him?  Little details like this add to the magic.  Arkham City also begs the question, "Why is everything in here blown up and ruined?" and we get answers to that too.  In fact, it's pretty breathtaking the first time you set foot into the Gotham of Arkham Origins and it's not only whole, it's colorful and lit up for Christmastime.The beginning of the game establishes that right now the cops in Gotham City are really corrupt, and Jim Gordon is one of the few who isn't on the take from mobs and/or supervillains.  It also sets the stage for a mostly-empty city by saying a severe storm has forced evacuation...leaving us with cops and criminals wandering around looking for a fight.Unfortunately, the much larger territory and more open-world feel also take us away from a sense of the story's urgency.  Arkham Asylum walked you on a path to the final battle, and it was a big important fight.  Arkham City played connect-the-dots with the main story elements and its 'Protocol Ten' countdown really built the tension.  Arkham Origins hits you the wrong way at both ends:  storylines swearing you need to act fast aren't affected if you decided to wander around and explore...and at the same time, random police alerts go off on the radio and after the first dozen red-alert alarm calls you start to feel like stopping crimes won't make a difference because 30 seconds later there will be another one demanding you answer it...but not really meaning anything except lost XP if you don't.The Good:We have beautiful graphics on the PCCombat flow is intricate and harder--you really need to take a more defensive stance and be willing to give yourself an edge by using gadgets.The achievement trees are hard to navigate because it appears that you have to knock out most of the achievements in order.The storyline does make the boss battles vary, though for the most part the combinations you use aren't any different from the prior games.We get some great dialog.  For example, (minor spoiler here) that first exchange in which Gordon meets Batman, that we've seen played over and over in movies and books, has Jim basically saying, "We have a system!" (and vigilantes don't fit) and Batman calmly responding, "If your system worked, I wouldn't be here."The Bad:Bugs can deny you an achievement.  They can cause the combat flow to come to a halt.  They can punish you for blocking because someone else got inserted in between you and your opponent.  An exciting multiple-takedown move usually starts with Batman popping up in the air, time slowing down...and then there's about a 50/50 chance that the move breaks and nothing happens.  Combat seems far too eager to take guy-with-knife and lock you into having to take him on head-to-head, even when you're ridiculously far away and moving further.  At least one bug has had me finish one of the hardest boss battles I've ever faced, only to be unable to leave the arena.  We've had major fixes released, but this one hit me again just last week.  More than one time I've had to reload a checkpoint and replay to re-earn what I'd rightfully accomplished.  And there are times when someone you're supposed to interrogate simply can't be interacted with--leave the area and/or reload.Really, given that 'more of the same' would make me happy, it's the bugs that make Arkham Origins such a disappointment.The Ugly:It was kind of fun in the earlier games having to take snapshots of clues to answer the Riddler--that has been removed and I suspect it's because it was too hard or required too much Batman knowledge.  We don't have green question marks, so instead we collect green data packets.  Some of the data packets won't be there until you Interrogate one of the bad guys, which can get annoying when the packet in question requires a long one-way walk back through a level you've completed...and in one case the Interrogate suspect never showed due to a bug and I had to keep waiting until another time and checking again until he did make an appearance.  Some of these one-way levels then require you to turn around and go all the way back to leave again.  It tends to turn things into a bit of a rote exercise, and that can be more frustrating when you realize that you're going to need to complete a large chunk of the main story just to be able to try your hand at the puzzles.  I won't spoil the game for you but I will say that one particular large confrontation turns into a nothing of non-battle, no exploration, just a tiny room and words exchanged.  The world is really huge, so they've added a 'fast travel' ability, but you won't be able to fast travel to an area until you've completely taken down a random scattering of items.  Last, playing 'New Game Plus' does NOT give you access to all of the gadgets you earned beating the game, but only those not central to the storyline...this is a shame because I really didn't want to repeat some of the boss battles and now that will be the only way to really get through the side stories, clues, and achievements.All in all, I loved the game enough to play it through twice, but I also found myself far more disappointed when things went wrong: it's like taking delivery of a beautiful Ferrari, only to find that the motor misfires and the Check Engine Light makes constant beeping noises. reviewText: When I realized we weren't getting an F-Zero game on the Wii, & no Burnout, I thought I'd never play a Wii racing game besides Mario Kart. Boy was I wrong....so VERY wrong. This game is crazy, & I mean crazy. If you know what you're doing, this game can provide tons of creativity & excitement. If you're not good at the game it can seem slow paced when it's actually a very fast paced game from start to finish. Throw in some crazy power ups, ramps that would make Evil Kenevil have nightmares,  & monster tricks, & you got yourself your Nintendo exclusive substitute for those who were craving an F-Zero game like me. It's way cooler than F-Zero in the sound department as you can add your own music from an SD card. summary: A Fine Welcome Home to Gothic Fans
reviewText: Risen was made by Pirahna Bytes, the same scrappy outfit that put together the first Gothic games, and this is basically Gothic with just a different name.  Like the earlier games, Risen takes a little time to get into, but once you do the rewards are great.  One of the best parts of Gothic and Gothic II was that exploring and being clever are incentivized and rewarded.  In many games, like Oblivion, so much is tied to your level that really you have no incentive to do anything other than level up and hope for the best.  Risen takes this away by scattering the world with treasure chests, rare loot, combinable alchemy items, and a wide array of NPCs that can give you quests, treasure, and experience rewards.  What this means is that there are many ways to develop your character; you can ignore the plots/quests and wander off into the woods, or hole up in the towns and run errands or engage in palace intrigues to get experience and levels.Indeed, like the Gothic games, Risen starts off as a struggle.  You will have poor equipment, terrible fighting skills, few resources, and no idea what is going on.  A single boar or wolf can kill you, and god help you if you wander off the main roads into a cemetery or swamp.  Many people find this challenging learning curve and free form environment frustrating, because you die a lot and do quests "wrong" or "out of order."  Who cares?  Gradually, so slowly you may not notice it at first, you get stronger.  By spending precious learning points (earned 10 every level) with NPC trainers, you can increase your combat skills, unlocking new moves and faster ranged attacks.  Spending points on blacksmithing will let you craft sharper swords, reforge pieces of magical weapons you find in the ruins, or even create protective magical jewelry to defend yourself.  Greater strength permits you to both do greater direct damage, and also to use stronger weapons -- the difference between 40 strength and using a bastard sword, and 50 strength and using a sharp two handed sword is far more significant than just the 10 strength difference might suggest.  You also go from clumsily hacking with a sword and being torn to pieces by packs of foes to fluidly sweeping your greatsword in big circles, slaughtering multiple monsters at a time.  But opportunities abound for any style of character -- use a crossbow to anger monsters and then lure them into towns where allies will assist you.  Get up on ledges or in narrow chokepoints to take on enemies one at a time.  Use a wide array of spells to attack, avoid, or outrun foes.Risen's graphics aren't great, and you will see some texture stretching (particularly on hills).  But the gameplay is very rewarding.  By collecting recipes, herbs, and buying Alchemy 3 you can suddenly make dozens of permanent stat boosting potions, and then wield one of those unique swords you picked up in your travels.  The map makes the island look small, but it is riddled with complex cave systems, ruined castles (often with secret passageways or catacombs), elaborate river and swamp systems, and soaring mountain passes.  Areas often have multiple entrances and exits, so if you are daring you can often sneak through places to grab treasure while avoiding particularly dangerous monsters you can't handle yet.  It's hard to overstate the gratification level when, after hours of getting chased around and eaten by black wolves or packs of gnomes, you can finally afford to buy that powerful crossbow or manage to sneak up a hidden river into the mountain and find a berserker sword or rune shield.  Soon monsters that you feared are instead valuable sources of experience points and lootable hides and teeth, and you're on to the next challenge.If you ever played and enjoyed Gothic or Gothic II, you owe it to yourself to play Risen.  Another nice feature for this console port is you can set up hotkey buttons for healing items and the like, often the difference between life and death.  Whether it's sneaking into people's houses at night to steal their loot, tiptoeing around behind stalagmites with your heavy crossbow while a blind Ashbeast pounds the floor all around you, or crushing a horde of skeletal warriors one at a time in the middle of a narrow rope bridge, you will find that the overall experience of Risen vastly exceeds the sum of its parts.

reviewText: RE5 is most definitely a refinement of RE4, that much will be obvious to fans of the series after the first few minutes. But its definitely not a bad thing, RE4 was one of the best games of its time and almost all of its weakness have been improved or fixed in Resident Evil 5. The over the shoulder 3rd person perspective will also be familiar. It is different from most shooters and takes some adjustments. But once you adapt to it you will find a good amount of control and precision to be had. There are frustrations and some of the bosses can be quite annoying, but you feel as if you have accomplished something when you finally beat a particularly difficult fight.You will do more shooting in RE5 than past games, but ammo usage and inventory are as important as ever. The graphics are simply amazing, though much of the blood and gore are a bit over the top at times. The AI for enemies is good, though in single player the AI for your partner suffers at times. Often times she will stand in front of enemy fire and she isn't once to conserve ammunition. That said she does a good job of watching your back. Some players will except the limitations and enjoy while others will use her more as a pack mule and carefully control her inventory. The whole problem is easily resolved when playing with another human in coop mode. Which is where the game really starts to shine. Granted a portion of the ambiance and fear created in the series to date has been the feeling of being utterly alone, which you won't get in this game. But the ability to share in the terror with another player doesn't necessarily lessen it, it just makes it different.I don't think RE5 is a ground breaking entry into the series, but it is a refinement of everything that was good with the last one. Those looking to recapture what made the original great will not find it in RE5. But this game stand on its own as a great entry into the series and more importantly than anything else is very fun to play.

I'll be the first to admit this game starts of slowly. After the first hour, my impression of this game was that it was a cheap, generic, Arkham Asylum knock-off. I came really close to trading it in, but I decided to stick with it.The one thing that makes this game different than many of the others is the use of counter attacks. When an enemy is about to strike you or shoot at you, an indicator will appear on the screen, and if you time your block just right, you'll retaliate with a vicious blow, or knock their bullets right back at them! I thought that was really cool and I had fun doing that.Yes, the combat was borrowed from Arkham Asylum, but it was still fun to fight, nonetheless. I do wish they would have tweaked the combat just a bit though, like maybe allow Captain America to jump in the air. Batman and Captain America are the only 2 action games that I know of that does not make use of a 'jump' button. In most games, the jump button is 'X', in this game, that just makes you roll/dodge. If you've played Arkham Asylum, the combat is pretty much identical. If you have not played AA, just imagine a free-flow combat system that allows you punch, kick, and counter; if all timed correctly, can be a thing of beauty. You are also able to use your shield in combat by throwing it at people, which is very fun to do.The only weapon that Cap uses is his Shield, which is plenty enough. Through upgrades, you'll be able to hit multiple enemies with one throw which will definitely come in handy as you progress through the game.The enemies in the game can be fun to fight at times, but I wish there were more of a variety. I may be wrong, but it seems to be only about 5 or 6 different enemy types, if that. But, this games does shine when it comes to the boss battles. I pretty much died the first few times I had to fight a new boss. You will continue to die until you figure out a strategy to defeat the boss. This is not a hack and slash game where you press the same button over and over to defeat a boss, which is a good thing in my book.Many people have mentioned how short the game is. Well, if you take your time to explore and look for hidden items, you can get about 12 hours out of it. If you just play through without exploring anything and without doing any of the challenges, you'll probably get about 8 or 9 hours.There are a couple of reasons as to why I deducted a star. I really wanted to see a better variety of enemies. Sure, the boss battles were fine, but I kept seeing the same enemies over and over. And also, this game copied AA too much. I'm not saying that was a bad thing, but AA is a unique game with a unique formula, come up with your own formula.I'm glad I stuck with it though; it turned out to be a fun game after all. It's not the type of game that's gonna set the world on fire, so please don't expect that. It's a fun game at a reasonable price that will keep you busy for a few hours, depending on how you play it.

This game is really entertaining, and the story and pacing are excellent. What surprised me the most was the level of the voice acting, it's a really great selection of voices for the characters and their acting was awesome, though there is this one thing that keeps bugging me: voice actors should pronounce Japanese names correctly, not as English speakers think these foreign names ought to be pronounced, otherwise it sounds too weird and disrupts the player's immersion within the game. Other than that (and perhaps the trippy opening), everything in this game was done in an wonderful manner.

description: The third title of the Gran Turismo series takes full advantage of the new PlayStation2 game engine, which is capable of rendering about 20 million polygons per second--roughly 10 times the number of total polygons of the series' previous installment,Gran Turismo 2. Real-time lighting forces your eyes to adjust to changing conditions, such as when a car rounds a turn and the sun comes out from behind a building to cause glare on the windshield. This makes the game harder, but more realistic. Heat rises off the ground and mist swirls around vehicles as they make their way across the racetrack.Gran Turismo 3also features more than 100 distinct cars, each with different statistics, including the Subaru Impreza Rally, Dodge Viper GTS-R, and Mazda's RX-7 RS. Computer-controlled opponents benefit from enhanced artificial intelligence; they don't act like baby ducks following their mother, but instead respond to other cars, the course, and the conditions in much the same way that real drivers would. Pressure a car, and it will pressure you back; cut one off in the early part of the race, and expect to receive similar treatment down the course. They don't drive perfectly, either; some will spin out and make other mistakes over the course of a race.
reviewText: This is a fun game.  If you've been following the Gran Turismo series you'll be impressed with this new version.  The cars are amazing and the graphic details is brilliant.  The soundtrack could use a little work but it's not too bad.  This game is great for all ages.

description: This action shooter takes place on a mysterious alien world. It offers a combination of team-based first-person-shooter gameplay (reminiscent ofTribes) and third-person vehicle combat elements. Gameplay kicks off with the player heading down to the planet's surface in a troop carrier, à laAliens. As the player and fellow marines exit, the remaining troopers form a flank in reaction to an oncoming onslaught of human and alien enemies.It's this smart AI system that makes for a noticeably unique gameplay feel. Another very nice feature is the seamless transition into vehicular elements. As you venture through mission objectives, a variety of enemy flyers and on-ground buggies are yours for the taking. Come across a vehicle and the camera will pull back to a third-person view as you strap in and motor through crossfire. A co-op mode allows a friend to join you in the single-player missions. For chaotic fighting action, up to four players can duel in split-screen deathmatch mode or link systems for LAN play. However you choose to hero your way throughHalo: Combat Evolved, the action should break in your new Xbox in explosive style.

description: Go for the ultimate trophy! Deer Drive: Legends takes you to the far corners of the earth where you will go after wild animals rarely seen by the human eye, some even believed to be extinct! Captured in rich, 3D environments, these animals are both elusive and quick! Stalk different species of elk, deer, big cats and more in the most exciting and realistic game available for Nintendo 3DS!
reviewText: When it has came down to Nintendo, they have had some really strong games that have changed the way we play video games for the better, and very rarely games are offered for the worse. Well, this third-party title isn't exactly one of those games. There have been a lack of really good shooter games for Nintendo. While they have had some excellent ones for the Wii, and from the Gamecube eras, they haven't actually shown that strength for the Nintendo DS and the 3DS either. That strain has dropped for hard core shooters getting into the 3DS, to get games like Call Of Duty and others. Nintendo tried their own hands on it with Metroid: Prime Shooters for the original Nintendo DS. While that game was good, the control scheme was lacking. Now, that Maximum Family Games have decided to make their own shooter for the 3DS, the question is do they deliver a really high-quality game.Deer Drive Legends for thew Nintendo 3DS, isn't exactly a game for everyone, yet it isn't actually a strong game either. While the game shows like it is promising, it actually isn't. The gameplay is simple, you're a hunter trying to shoot at hard hitting and raving mad deer to score points for your ranking. The graphics are good, but the control is very sloppy. Instead of it being streamlined, it falls shy because of the clunky controls, and the constant swerving in the gameplay. It can be very harsh and unfortunately, you wind up constantly losing in the game. While you do have your hands in a set of guns from rifle, and to handguns and bullets. You do sometimes constantly get to recharge your guns without realizing you get hit. Not to mention the music is definitely not as interesting. All in all, there was more that was needed to be tuned up and it just wasn't there.Overall, if you are looking for a alternative game for the Nintendo 3DS, Deer Drive Legends 3DS isn't exactly a great game, nor is it really anything worth its while. I actually wasn't impressed with the game, and had really wanted more. If there is going to be another Deer Drive game for any Nintendo system, let's hope that the controls can be better for a more enjoyable game next time around. I would definitely wait for a better shooter to come around that is more worth its money.Graphics: B-Sound: CControl: D+Fun & Enjoyment: COverall: C 1/2-

description: Far Cry 2 by Ubisoft is the anticipated sequel to the award-winning original that brings players into the beautiful and hostile world of Africa. Far Cry 2 for Windows Vista/XP features open-ended gameplay that allows you to play the game whichever way you choose, with the choices you make affecting where the game leads you..caption { font-family: Verdana, Helvetica neue, Arial, serif; font-size: 10px; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic; } ul.indent { list-style: inside disc; text-indent: -15px; } table.callout { font-family: verdana; font-size: 11px; line-height: 1. 3em; } td.vgoverview { height: 125px; background: #9DC4D8 url(http://images.amazon.com/images/G/01/electronics/detail-page/callout-bg.png) repeat-x; border-left: 1px solid #999999; border-right: 1px solid #999999; padding-left: 20px; padding-right: 20px; padding-bottom: 10px; width: 250px; font-family: verdana; font-size: 12px; }Far Cry 2Players:Offline: 1Online: 16Multiplayer Modes:Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Capture the Diamond, UprisingFormat:Native 720p high-definition output.Far Cry 2 brings you to Africa where you'll explore the savannah and the jungle.View larger.Features real-time night-and-day cycles and smart enemy AI.View larger.Outstanding GraphicsUbisoft developed the Dunia Engine specifically for Far Cry 2. Among other things, the Dunia Engine delivers realistic, interactive environments, special effects, real-time night-and-day cycles, and smart enemy AI.Expansive, Realistic EnvironmentFar Cry 2 is set in a fictional region of Africa where you are caught between two rival factions at war. The Ubisoft team spent a lot of time filming and photographing in Africa to get all the details of the landscape and native wildlife. The result is a huge gameplay area that is 50 square kilometers, taking players into and out of the jungle and savannah. Wild animals such as zebras, buffalo, gazelle are encountered during the game, with both players and enemies allowed to interact with them.Far Cry 2 features an incredible level of detail and realism, with a minimal in-game interface to detract from immersion. For example, players will need to navigate the world using an in-game map and navigation system, weapons will disintegrate over time, and fires will spread and propagate.Each of the actions a player takes is reflected in the environment and changes the content of the game. To fulfill your mission, you need to play the enemies against each other, using both strategy and skill.Huge Range of Weapons and VehiclesFar Cry 2 offers gamers a wide range of weapons, from a machete for hand-to-hand combat, to a sniper rifle that can stealthily pluck off enemies from afar. As weapons disintegrate over time, they might jam or even explode in your hand.There are also a large range of vehicles such as gliders, trucks, cars, and boats that will let you fly, drive, slide, and hover over the open landscapes.Multiplayer Options for up to 16 PlayersFar Cry 2 supports up to 16 players and has four gameplay modes: Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Capture the Diamond, and Uprising. Players can choose from six different classes in multiplayer, each with its own set of pros and cons. description: When people ask me what my favorite game of all time is, I always answer the same thing:Metroid. Sure,Super Metroidon SNES took the concept and made it better, andMetroid Fusionwas a fantastic follow-up on the Game Boy Advance, but when push comes to shove the original is where my vote will always go. Then there'sMetroid Prime…but that's 3D and a story for a different day. This game and this story are all about the glory of 2D gaming.So you can only begin to imagine my excitement when Nintendo's newestMetroidredo appeared on my desk. For those of you that may not know,Zero Missionis a special edition of sorts. It's the originalMetroidwith spruced-up graphics, streamlined level designs and gameplay, plus a whole new chapter.At it's core, it is most definitely the originalMetroid, but as you travel around the world you start to notice differences. Hallways are changed, statues lead you to the next objective, and abilities like Power Grip and Space Jump that never existed in the original iteration pop up in time.Nintendo has been very hush-hush about this title since its announcement, and after playing through the game myself, I must admit I'm a little reluctant to give away too much, but I can give you some interesting facts to whet your whistle. The biggest chunk of new content takes place after you beat Mother Brain (which was where the original ended). Not only is this new zone fairly large (I would say it's bigger than Norfair and Brinstar combined) it incorporates a number of story elements that help tie the whole series together (includingMetroid Prime).In total, the game is still rather short. I beat it in roughly six and a half hours, and I wandered around a lot. But the new content is spectacular, and fans of the series will absolutely adore this special edition. And if you have never experiencedMetroid, then you are in for a treat. My one rip on this title is the fact that the game now holds your hand a little too much, so the title loses some of the wonder and puzzle solving that I loved about the original. But don't let this one setback stop you from picking up one of the greatest titles in the history of gaming.Concept:Update a classic with new graphics and lots of bonus materialGraphics:Crisp 2D sprites jump off your SP or GBA PlayerSound:Fantastic from beginning to endPlayability:Metroid's control set-up is still one of the most simple, yet complex schemes ever created – brilliantEntertainment:Replaying the original with added content is an 8-bit gamers dream come trueReplay:ModerateRated:9.5 out of 10Editor:Andy McNamaraIssue:February 20042nd Opinion:Much like the extended editions of The Lord of the Rings movies, Nintendo has reworked the originalMetroidto feature bonus content that ties into Samus' continuing adventures. I can't even begin to tell you how amazing this new material is. Let's just say that you're in for a big surprise after the Mother Brain fight. A huge surprise! I don't want to ruin the game for you, but I will say that there's a stretch of the game that I played with my jaw on the floor. Better yet, all of the original content has been extensively overhauled. The shape of the terrain has been altered dramatically, and as you progress through this incredible adventure you'll spot subtle changes every step of the way. With the original NES game included as a bonus, you'll get the chance to compare and contrast. Nintendo took one of the best games of all time and made it better. Buy it immediately.Rated:9.75 out of 10Editor:Andrew ReinerSubscribe to Game Informer--Game Informer Review

You are a fan of the Metroid series;2.  You thoroughly enjoyed the original game;3.  If you have a Gameboy Advance.

description: Nintendo DS Lite, Polar WhiteLighter! Brighter! Let the cool look of the Polar White DS Lite brighten your day! summary: Fantastic Value in a Gaming System
reviewText: We owned an original Nintendo DS for two years - we bought it right when it released in December 2004. When I first saw the DS Lite at E3 in 2006, I was thrilled. The game great handheld unit design - but lighter! Brighter! Tuned! It really showed that Nintendo had been paying attention to customer feedback during those two years, and had tweaked its unit to be even better than before.First, the weight. We always *loved* the design of the DS, with its folding top. As PSP owners, I can't tell you how many time that poor PSP screen gets dinged or scratched. We had to buy extra carrying cases for our PSP and get screen protectors. In comparison, the DS's clamshell design means the screen is perfectly protected when you tote it around in your pocket or purse. The only down-side was that it was a bit heavy. With the DS lite, they keep the protection of the clamshell and also lighten up the unit significantly. It really does help a lot.The screen brightness - with it being *adjustable* - is an incredibly helpful update. Sometimes you're playing outside in very bright light. Sometimes you're playing in full dark, staying awake in bed. There are all levels in between. If you need that brightness, you don't care if you're burning up your battery power. If you do NOT need that brightness, why kill your battery for no reason? Having that ability to adjust really means that your battery works as best as it possibly can.We play several games that use the microphone, like Brain Age, and it definitely helps to have it in the center. Usually you're holding the unit with both hands, centered on your face. To have your mouth pointed right at the microphone helps out greatly with those games.In general the DS system is a fantastic handheld gaming system. We have both the DS and PSP and we play both frequently. Many of the games on the DS aren't available on the PSP and are a ton of fun. The Brain Age / Big Brain Academy / similar games stand out as games we enjoy daily. There are many other games that use the DS touch screen extremely well, giving a full interactivity of gameplay. Yes, the PSP has better graphics. It's something that the DS compromised on. They have less detailed graphics, but more interactivity. Both are great for the games they offer. So for example we play flight simulator style games on our PSP, where the high end graphics matter, and we play puzzle / platform / thinking games on the DS, where the interactivity and plot is more key.I highly recommend the DS Lite for anybody who doesn't have a DS yet - whether you have a PSP or not. It's not an either-or situation. It's like having a stereo and a TV set. They're both great for their own reasons, and most people would enjoy having both.If you HAVE a Nintendo DS already and are wondering if you should get a Lite, it really depends on how much you use it away from home. The primary benefit here is the lighter carrying weight, smaller size and much better battery life. If you're carrying it in your pocket, purse or backpack every day, I would really recommend getting a Lite. You can always give your original DS away to a friend or relative as a present, or sell it on eBay. The DSs are still in high demand and would be much loved by a new recipient.

With plot twists hiding around every corner, NIER's story needs to be seen to be believed.RPG Gameplay Injected With Action-Packed Combat:Battle ferocious and mysterious enemies by combining proven RPG-style gameplay, such as magic, character development and faithful allies, with action-focused explosive swordplay and combat.Powerful Magical Abilities:When his sword isn't enough, Nier can call on a remarkable array of stylish and powerful spells to augment his combat moves and overcome adversaries. Unlock an arsenal of devastating weapons, each with its own design and attack style.Formidable Allies:Travel with a dynamic party of allies and do battle against monstrous giants as a powerful and united party.A Dynamic and Stunning World:Travel across an unforgettable world filled with dynamic landscapes featuring the hauntingly familiar remains of modern society.Product DescriptionJump into the title role of the unyielding Nier as he begins his desperate quest to discover a cure for his daughter, Yonah, who is stricken with the deadly Black Scrawl disease. summary: One of the best stories you'll ever experience.
reviewText: I play video games for their story and here is my top five now that I've finished Nier:1.  Xenogears2.  Xenosaga series3.  Nier4.  Planescape: Torment5.  Final Fantasy XThis game is a MASTERPIECE when it comes to the story and never have I seen a game tell its story the way Nier does.  Basically you play through the game, then have the opportunity to play through it again.  And playing through it again is NOT just the same story with a different ending, prepare to have your eyes opened and to be hit in the gut ad you experience it all from a new perspective.  It's very emotional and amazing.So I made it clear, the story of Nier is original and incredible.  What about everything else?  Well, the soundtrack is one of the best I've heard and the voice acting it out of this world.  Not everything is as amazing though.  The world is kind of small and there is a LOT of back tracking through the same locations over and over.  The side quests can be a terrible grind for little reward, but some of them tell great stories too so it's worth it to push through.  The game isn't perfect, but the story is so good this game MUST be played.And I will say this final statement:  If you put in the time to play through Nier once and watch the final credits, you are doing yourself the ULTIMATE disservice if you do not do the Newgame+ feature.  Actually you could say you haven't even beaten the game or seen the story unless you have at least played through twice.

This game has been criticized by some reviewers for being repetitive, for having enemies look all the same (as opposed to in the movies, where they look...all the same?) and one reviewer (Game Informer) went so far as to criticize it because the enemies get harder.In my opinion, the game can get a bit repetitive, (although it is a hack and slash, and I would think  someone picking up a hack and slash would understand there's a certain level of grind involved) and although the graphics are very lush, the enemies do kinda look all the same, although I really didn't care that much about that peculiar quirk. I'm not even going to dignify the complaint about difficulty scaling. As the game progresses, it gets harder, ok? If you want to god-mode it up, go re-play the first stages of the game. Also, the game DOES allow you to grind beyond what should be 'at level' for the current content.The bigger issue going on with this game would be the glitches. Some are minor, such as sound stuttering. Some are a bit lame, such as not being able to land crits, at all.  And some, are just really infuriating. Such as not being able to progress through the story after a certain point.I bought the game on release, I was really gung ho about it, and about  a few days in, I got stuck in Mirkwood. I was not able to progress the story at about the halfway point of the game. I found a quick fix online- apparently some people in the same situation were getting through the glitch by joining a co-op match. So I did, and it worked. And then I got stuck by a similar glitch on the next stage.The game came out  a month ago, and I haven't played it in about 3 weeks. What's more frustrating is that Snowblind is well aware of these and many more glitches, and they are supposedly currently working on a patch. Have been working. On a patch. For 3 weeks to a month.Truth be told, this game was meant to be a fun game to play while I waited for other games to come out later this year. Most of those games have come out now. I would have liked to finish this game (and probably will once Snowblind lets me) but not being able to really puts a downer on the entire experience.I would say, buyer beware.5/7/2012 Post-Patch update: I have picked this up again, finally finished it, saw there's a +Game feature, which I'm a fan of. All in all, it's a fun game, but even after the patch I'm still  seeing that the game will, at random, delete random quests from my open quest log (example, in the Barrens, found the Athelas, kept questing, turned it off, came back a bit later, went back to the camp, and found out I didn't have that quest any more...really frustrating)From what I've read in the forums is that the "fix" or work around is simply to quit the game, and reload it, and voila, the missing quest should be there. This work around works, but then you're subjected to the really long load times.  Better than nothing.

reviewText: As a hardcore FPS guy (first person shooter for those of you that don't know. i.e. Call of Duty, MAG, Battlefield games) I wanted to try to mix it up a bit. Truly the only other non-FPS game I play is Little Big Planet and that's really for spending quality time with my wife more than anything. :)As for Heavy Rain; I liked it, I really did. But I do wish there was a bit more depth in the story. I have only run through the story once so I'm not sure if the origami killer is different every time but the few "chapters" I played over did change a bit allowing me to unlock a few more trophies (if you're into that sorta thing.)Overall, a solid buy as a used game but I'm not sure it will give you the hundreds of hours I get from a good FPS. I picked this up new whereas I had a $20 giftcard from a recent Battlefield Bad Company 2 pre-order bonus from Amazon. $35 for this game was a fair price, but I don't know if I would spend $60 since it's really not my sort of game. In any case, a solid 4 star game.

Below I will have 2 sets of reviews..  one for the game.  one for the CE additions you pay $20 for...___ Dead Space 2: The game ___Dead space 2 picks up some time after the original and literally seconds after Dead Space: Ignition.  From that point on this game pulls no punches and puts the cheesy scares behind for some downright terrifying segments.  Being this game plays out like the first, where you mainly see Issac's view supplemented by various logs you find, I don't blame Issac for being crazy!  From the moment the game starts you are put on the roller-coaster and there just doesn't seem to be an end in sight.Graphics: Fantastic compared to Dead Space.  The back of the box lists 1080i as the resolution but this actually is a miss-print.  The game is 1080p and looks fantastic.  Dark, spooky , flickering lights.  Blood and weapon effects.  They are well polished and you can tell they put a lot of effort into making this game look good. If a room is pitch black it was meant to be pitch black.  Monsters are well detailed, and Issac has a much more fluid setup this time.  He no longer moves clunky which helps with aiming plus making his movements feel more natural and realistic to the playerSound/Story: The atmosphere is great. They didn't hold back with the voice acting and ambient sound.  You walk into a room and hear some glass break yet see nothing.  Echo's down halls and footsteps through the duct-work.  Everything is well polished and sets you up for a scary, horrifyingly good time.  The storyline is fairly good, with Issac having more of a say in the story this time.  That's right folks, Issac can talk now.  I won't ruin the storyline with the review but I think it definitely adds more dimension to the overall tale being told here.Gameplay: The gameplay is smooth and that goes with the presentation and graphics and audio.  Everything meshes well together and while a few things might irk the dedicated Dead Space player (new controls take some time to get used to) they work out for the best.  The new weapons are a blast and the suit designs are very nice.  There are a multitude of ways to kill mobs now ; simple killing, dismember a limb and impale them, plant mines, stick em with a javelin then fry the mob walking by the pinned mob.  There also appears to be a few different methods to attacking rooms (way mobs spawn/trigger).  Another prime example of the gameplay polish is audio logs don't just spring up and play. You have to hit select to play them.  Also your "objective location" line from the first game now can locate SAVE, OBJECTIVE, STORE and BENCH locations.  A very nice feature.Length/Replay:  The chapters come across shorter than the first game, but I feel there is more content here at the same time.  It is concentrated you could say.  Not nearly as much downtime, but keep in mind there is 15 chapters I believe.  Dead Space had 12  so said +3 chapters makes up for the quicker paced chapters.  Overall I think the game clocks in at about the length of Dead Space if my calculations are correct.  The replay value is through the roof once again; Game+ modes  plus you have tons of difficulties to test out, let alone items seem better hidden this time (or so I am finding). Mainly logs and kind of bonus stuff.Overall: This game is a big hit in my book.  If you loved the 1st game this game easily will top  your expectations.  It brings everything Dead Space had plus throws on a helping of Necromorph icing and delicious scare/horror cookies.  This game gets a 95% in my book (A) and is a must have for any Dead Space fan  or survival/horror buff.___ Collector's Edition ___For $20 extra you get lots of goodies like you should expect from a CE.  I will break down the goodies by how I feel, influences your $ spent1. Lithograph ( 10 pts)  - This must be worth maybe... $0.10  its just a glossy image on a sheet of paper.  Single Sided and honestly not all that memorable.  It just shows you the necro-morph transformation steps2. Official Sound track ( 85 pts) - This is pretty good.  I'd say maybe $4.99 - $6.99 in value comes in a nice little DS2 CE sleeve and contains 18 tracks.  The audio quality is very good and the music already got me pumped for some DS2 action!3. DLC content ( 80 pts) - Pretty good again, as your code will unlock a Zealot Force Gun and Suit  (probably a $2.99 - $3.99 value)  These are CE only items as you can not buy them through the PSN store (but EA does tend to change their mind)4. Dead Space 2 Video game - I hope your box has a game in it ^_^ hehe (all CE editions contain the LIMITED EDITION version of the game)5. Dead Space Replica Plasma Cutter (85pts)-- This is actually MORE than I expected.  I knew it was just going to be 6in and had no fully movable parts (the one at the E3 show was an exact replica / demo)  The plasma cutter is pretty simple looking, nothing fancy.  It has a flashlight on it, and 3 LED's for aiming.  There is two problems I have however.  NO BATTERIES?!?!?  On top of no batteries the screw being used to hold the covering for the batteries requires an eyeglass screw driver.  The device takes 2 AAA  batteries.  The other is, the aimer doesn't pivot like in the video game.  So you are stuck using it the "primary" fire mode way.-- Aside from that the replica is pretty nifty.  It comes with a resealable plastic bag (zip lock) and once the batteries are installed, there is a white LED flashlight on the side that illuminates.  3 tiny Green LED lights for the aiming beams.  The trigger gives a reassured "click" when pressed and feels sturdy.-- Overall this is awesome!  I wasn't expecting this to be made of metal or aluminum let alone be a full working model like people were hoping for. That would of been a $120 CE like the Killzone 3 Collectors Edition. This is what it is...a nice little piece to keep handy in case some necromorphs decide to storm in on your DS2 play time6. Dead Space Extraction (100 pts) - are you kidding me?!  A free  100% full game with 100% move support!  Nuff said  (the graphics are also remastered in 720p  vs the 480p the Wii had)overall the CE scored 360 points, however I am eliminating the lithgraph from the score netting it 350pts.  Over 4 items that is a 87.5 or B+ score.*** This CE is well worth $20 extra.  A replica plasma cutter... a DLC exclusive suit and gun..  The OST... and a FULL GAME!  Seriously... you get 2 games in this box with a CE.  Even without the replica, DLC and OST  that's just $20 for  Dead Space Extraction  If you are on the edge, pick up the CE.**NOTE:  However, the CE edition for the Xbox360 and PC  I would be hesitant about.  If you remove the 100pts earned by literally having a free game for the PS3, you end up with 260 pts and I am now INCLUDING the lithograph since 360 and PC copies do not get a free game... That scores you a 65  or a D+.  At this point now it is pretty much a "PASS"  The only thing even worth getting your hands on is the Replica as the DLC and OST are negligible in the long run.  So if you are going to get the PS3 version, the CE is worth your money simply because you get Extraction free of charge.  If you get the PC or 360 versions, Skip the CE and get the Regular edition******EDIT 1/29/2011There is some confusing about the Limited Edition vs the Collectors Edition vs the Regular partially to blame is EA as they didn't go out of their way to mention the differencesREGULAR COPY of Dead Space 2 =  Dead space 2 retail +  DEMO of Dead Space Extraction ($59.99)LIMITED EDITION of Dead Space 2 =  Dead space 2 + FULL copy of Dead Space extraction ($59.99 limited prints many places already are selling out)COLLECTORS EDITION of Dead Space 2 = LIMITED EDITION + DLC + Plasma Cutter Replica + Official Soundtrack + Lithograph of Art ($79.99)The PC and 360 versions  do not contain Dead Space Extraction (Sony PS3 exclusive)Dead Space Extraction currently is a $23.99 retail value (however you can probably find it cheaper looking at independent sellers. I've seen it as low as $9.99 but as high as $26.99)** It was brought to my attention (see comments) that Dead Space extraction is now available on the PSN for just $14.99.  Not a bad price seeing as how the Wii version is retailing for $29.99 , on sale for $23.99

summary: Are you ready to lay the smack down with THQ for the final time? Oh Hell Yeah!
reviewText: THQ first burst onto the scene of wrestling games back in the late 90's when they released one of the best wrestling games of the time, WCW vs NWO. They got even better with it's follow up WCW vs NWO Revenge, and the more fans screamed for things to be added, the better THQ got, especially when they lost the rights to WCW and picked up the WWE and have held onto the rights up until this 2013th year. It was the Nintendo 64 smash hit No Mercy that took THQ to new heights by creating what some still consider to this day to be the best wrestling game ever. But the transition to newer consoles was a great but rough ride, but improving on a lot of things with each new game. The smackdown series on PS1 where good for the day, but are a mess when you look at them now, but they redeemed themselves when they made the first 3 smackdown games on the ps2. From there the famous Smackdown vs Raw games commenced, from the first on being developed in 2004, up till 2010, then they dropped the title and simply went with WWE 12. Now, in one final effort, how does the final THQ wrestling game come off?I have been a big fan of the SvsR games, but each one of them I had complaints about, as well as praises. But it looked as tho all THQ where worrying about was improving graphics when it came to SvsR 2009 and 2010. Many glitches, bugs and not much of a fun factor to be found with those updates, so much so I didn't even bother to play 12. I did however play 11, and they improved alot, but it still lacked in a lot of things.Now on the PS3. THQ have made their final WWE game. Unless they get the contract back later. Sure enough, they did put quite a lot of effort into this one. I did not play 12, so I can't compare it, but from what I have heard, I shouldn't even bother going backwards to 12 compared to 13.Sure enough, the graphics have been improved. As does it always in each release. And this time they have apparently added back the moves that people where ticked off about in 12 because it lacked in so many of them. However, this game does have a lot of moves not present, but for the most part, you should be able to find just about anything you desire to do.As usual, the exhibition matches are present. From 1 on 1, 2 on 2, 3 on 3, 6 man, whatever and customizable match condiations. TLC, Tables, Hardcore, Cage, Cell, Chamber, Scramble, Gauntlet, Rumbles,  inferno and all that from the past games are back again. What is not here from past games is Buried Alive, Pillow Fights and two things we have wanted, but have never been done is Ambulance and survivor series 4 on 4.Most things have remained the same as SVR2011. A few small changes have been made to inferno, hell in a cell, and rumble/over the top eliminations. But what hasn't been changed for the better is customizing rules in rumbles/royals to allow you to pin or exit the ring... nor has turning off KO in backstage fights. WHY? Oh, and neither has the men vs women is forbidden rubbish... but there is a codebreaker code for that at least.The main feature is Attitude mode. You get to participate in classic matches from the Attitude era. Starting off from he Rise of DX, to the rise of Stone Cold, The Rock, Mick Foley and then a few other random moments. Its not bad, it's fun. Can be tricky at times. But some details where left out, and that was disappointing... no mention of DX running to the ring to help Mick Foley win his first championship, just Stone Cold. Nor the moment when DX was born. I guess the WWE really do not want any footage of Chyna to be seen? During these matches, you can have a task to do, if you want, which will unlock something. These things might be something as simple as hit your finisher, or hit someone with a chair at a certain time. Others might be whack someone with a chair 100 times or do a whole heap of things in a set time limit. Nothing is overlay challenging, about the hardest I found was getting Chris Jericho to do the walls of Jericho then powerbomb them through the table. But you work it out eventually.Whats' surprisingly lacking is a few huge attitude moments that don't even get a mention. Chyna is not present at all in the game. Neither is Sable. I can understand Chyna, but what have they got against Sable now?Creating superstars has been improved a bit. Not a great deal more has been added, but you should be able to create what you want. A cool new feature tho is you can create your own drawing and use it. I think it may have already been introduced in past SVr games or 12, but this is the first one ive played on PS3.. having moved on from the PS2. It's allowed quite a lot of talented people to make better looking custom superstars who look more realistic then the generic stuff you have to work with. More announcer names have been included then ever before, yet that lacks when it comes to actual in game commentary names, which is a shame. It bugs me tho why so many names are in it, but the ones you really want are left out. There is a lack of names to match legends of the past, yet just about every Mortal Kombat name you can think of can be made! Making multiple attires is easier than ever before tho!As usual, you can also create entrances, and move sets. Create your own moves (2 maximum per wrestler tho) and also create your own arena... as well as story mode and belt.The coolest thing is now you can use your own mp3's as a entrance theme. Shame you can't pick one for each attire or an entrance and exit theme. It's also a shame so many entrance animations have not been included... pretty much just about everything is of an actual wrestler from the past. hardly any custom ones. (I miss the tricycle entrance)There is a fair amount to unlock. Some worth while, some a load of rubbish.I guess the reason I don't give the game 5 stars is because of so much that I expected to be in this game, but was not.Here we go with cons.- Glitches. There is quite a lot of them. Some are fun, but when the game freezes when changing participants in a Universe match. Irritating.- Nothing really new to play in. I don't know what more could be done, at least what the WWE would allow. But some sort of new matches would have been great.- Missing moves. Some moves I wanted are just not in the game. And then, some I did want, are available for DLC, which just makes you wonder why they were not just put in the game in the first place without having to download them?- Lack in announcer name choices. Why can you have during the entrance, but not during the match?- Lack of being able to create your own ring. They have the perfect chance now to add something great, where you can make your own ring. Pick the size, then the shape (TNA dont hold copyright on hexagon rings) then choose rope types.... wrestling/boxing/barbwire/no ropes. Then be able to create a cage around the ring. Even choose what side of the cage has what kind of cage? One side could be old school bars, the next new style mesh, the next is chain squared thingies, and the next could be a brick wall? Also, a choice of a roof on the cage? Be able to monkey bar to the middle and drop on your opponent. Dont stop there, also be able to create the cages around the barriers (hell in a cell) and have the same sort of options for each panel there. Could be cool to be able to have a cage match where instead of the cage being around the ring, you have to climb over an outside the ring hell in a cell structure to win. Be even cooler if you could create the cage around the ring AND the hell in a cell around it. Perhaps with no roof? A cage match where you have to escape two cages. Or even have a cage, surrounded by a hell in a cell, but ontop of the cell you can create another cage, with a cage on-top of that that contains the belt... or on top of that cage is a ladder. The possibilities in creating great new matches like that would be endless. Especially if you can add flames around the cages or even ontop of the cages.- Options to choose match options freely. No more set options in rumbles or what not. If you wanna take on 40 guys and have to make everyone submit or KO, then so be it. Bring back the freedom of No Mercy's options.- better, and I mean MUCH BETTER backstage areas. Including the above options thing. Bring back the great backstage areas like in the original Smackdown games where you could go to the parking lot, outside, subways, down town new york, hang off helicopters etc...- Create your own taunt.- Create your own submission move- Create your own other moves.- Create your own tag/trio/faction entrances (individual characters one at a time) If I want one guy to come out and flip the crowed off, while another comes down from the scaffold of the ceiling and another walks to the ring through the crowed... why should I be able to?)- Faction vs Faction matches/storyline/modes- Able to use your own video for an entrance screen- More weapons/or create your own weapons? Draw it, decide how it interacts, then use it.- Ability to beat up the commentators. The shut up when you hit them.- Go into the crowed. (tho, you can do this via a glitch)- Bring back the hardcore areas above the top right of the screen in normal matches- Allow more hotspots and things to do in the entrance areas. Especially being able to throw your opponent of stage. And personally, I wanna be able to climb the Titantron and take off.- Be able to go backstage at anytime from the arena (even if it's only in one match type)- More environment to interact with.- Scaffold Matches (after Owen Harts mishap, I doubt WWE would ever allow it)- DLC worth downloading.- Mini games? (I dunno, be able to go backstage and play basketball... hehehe maybe not?)- a training ring backstage somewhere, so when you're in a falls count only in the ring, but no count out, if you go backstage, there is another ring you can pin in... that could be a whole new match by itself)- Choose your own things that need to be done before a match can be completed.What else would you like to see?

summary: An interesting addition to the Bejeweled family of  matching games
reviewText: This game is the latest addition to the Bejewel line of games from "POPCAPS".The original 'Bejeweled' was a game of match 3, 4 or 5 jewels while trying to obtain a higher and higher scores as the game progressed in difficulty. 'Bejeweled Twist' adds several new options to the old game. The main difference is in movement of gems; in the original game you moved the gem laterally or up/down to make a match, but in B. Twist you turn 4 gems 90 degrees resulting is more combinations and also more unexpected result.Some other things I liked:1.)A very pleasant and catchy electronic tune plays continually in the background; in all the times I've played, I've never become annoyed or irritated by this melody. (it can, however, be turned off) The graphics/videos and audio effects (explosions etc.) are outstanding.2.)The old game ended if no match was available (who can ever forget "NO MORE MOVES" as your last desperate attempt to continue a game failed). However, in this game you always have a move; losing involves having a gem that has turned into a time bomb go off before you can destroy or defuse it. This can be very intense as the music pace increases and the bomb start to vibrate and smoke as the counter ticks down towards zero with each successive move .3.)Every move that makes a match, evokes a multiplier system that allows score to be gradually increased up to a factor of 10x, resulting in potentially incredible high scoring combos; it's very motivating to try to obtain these increasingly larger and larger multipliers.4.)'Special' gems are awarded once the 10x multiplier level meter is reach and filled twice, resulting in a rare, but astronomical scoring opportunity.5.)In addition to the regular 'Bejeweled Twist' matching game there are several other features; a Zen game (unending, no bombs and no tension), a Blitz game (5 minutes to get a new high score) and a Challenge game (where you need to accomplish certain goals to continue).Conclusion:A truly interesting addition to the Bejewel family of games; very addicting.Easily worth every cent of the less than $20.00 you pay to purchase.5 Stars.Ray Nicholson

description: The island of Banoi is a lush, tropical paradise in the South Pacific where its flagship Royal Palms Resort serves as the ultimate getaway for vacationers with money to burn. However, all good things must soon come to an end - and the picturesque resort falls into madness, carnage and chaos after a mysterious and contagious zombie outbreak claims its once peaceful atmosphere. Cut off from the rest of the world, only four individuals who strangely find themselves immune to zombification have the power to protect the remaining survivors from the horrors of the island, to discover what's really going on and find a way to escape before their own fatal ends.    Gameplay HighlightsIn keeping with an atmosphere of desperation and survival by any means, Dead Island focuses on serious,first-person actiongameplay with a close-quarter,immersive melee focus.Dead Island'sseamless 4 player co-op multiplayerseeks to provide the most immersive multiplayer experience to date. Players can drop in and out of each other's games at any time with no loss of progress as well as the ability to continue on alone or with others.Withthousands of weapons in-gameto collect, from simple wooden bats to fire-axes to heavy rifles, Dead Island is a collector's dream. This in combination with Dead Island'sweapon customization systemwill enable the player to craft the ultimate weapon to ensure their survival.The ability to enhance and develop your character usingRPG-like elementsincluding an XP/leveling system and un-lockable skill trees put the power in your hands to create and play a unique protagonist.Dead Island's damage system gives an unprecedented visual detail of the effects of each attack on enemies pushing the boundaries of visualized gore.With anopen-world setting, Banoi is filled to the brim with things to do and objectives to tackle, allowing a fresh way to advance both the characters and story at the same time and providing for endless replay value.
reviewText: I just finished it, including every side-quest, and therefore I can say I saw everything this game offers. And I should tell you - this is a great game. The story is not on a forefront, but there is a book already, which fleshes it out a bit. If to consider the story as a combination of a game and a book, it is actually a pretty interesting sci-fi thriller. We have cannibalism, international conspiracy, and a threat of pandemic at the end. It might look in the beginning that things do not make too much sense, but take it easy and wait for the third act (in the jungle), and everything will become clear.The game is beautiful, btw. The resort location is gorgeous, the city of Moresby is horrible but in an awesome kind of way, and the jungle, with its biochemical lab complex and an ancient burial ground, native villagers, and rebel hideouts is simply terrific.Killing zombies is fun, but probably not for everyone. It is kinda cruel, definitely not for kids.Character development is nice, though leveling-up never feels as an accomplishment, bec. zombies are getting stronger faster, and so the game is getting harder. But no worries, when you die all you have to do is to wait for 7 seconds, and loose some money. The progress in the game is not lost. This system worked well for me, no saves were ever corrupted. So everyone can reach the end.It took me 47.5 hours to finish it, and I did not get all collectibles. So the game is fairly long. Overall, this game was a very pleasant surprise. Now starting it again with a new character ;)

summary: A five star game that gets four, because when compared to its near-perfect predecessors, it's hard not to be let down a bit
reviewText: My review title really says everything I want to say about this game.Dark Souls II is amazing. But because it's not the 10/10 game that Demon's Souls and Dark Souls were, it's hard not to be a tad bit disappointed.Why isn't it on the level of its two forefathers? It's hard to say. Hidetaka Miyazaki wasn't at the helm of this game, like he was with the previous two games in the series. But honestly, my thoughts are that the reason is because Dark Souls II tried too hard to be a mix of its predecessors. While in theory this isn't a bad idea, I think the game ended up tripping over itself a bit at times. The game features an inter-connected world marked by bonfires serving as checkpoints, just like Dark Souls did. Yet it also brings back the concept of a "hub", a separate area where the player goes to level up, visit blacksmiths & vendors, interact with NPC's, and most importantly, fast travel anywhere, just like Demon's Souls did. So where as the world of Dark Souls felt like a brilliant, cohesive whole (which it was), Dark Souls II's world never feels that way. And at the same time, Dark Souls II's individual areas never feel quite as distinct and brilliantly designed the way Demon's Souls did. Part of this may have to do with the designers' desire to make this game more Demon's Souls-esque than Dark Souls was, but ultimately, it's the level design itself that is to blame. The level design is fantastic still, with some incredibly memorable locations. But it never really reaches the heights of the previous games, which is a shame.With that said, there is no denying that Dark Souls II is a still a wonderful game. If Demon's Souls and Dark Souls didn't exist, this game would be revolutionary. In fact, despite my 4 star rating, this game is still better than almost anything else out there. It's sure to be considered in any worthwhile Game of the Year conversation for 2014. It even does some things significantly better than previous entries in the Souls series. Most notably, it accomplishes the absolutely incredible feat of becoming a much more transparent, accessible game, while at the same time not losing an ounce of the depth, challenge, and high levels of player satisfaction that the series has been known for. Esoteric game mechanics like the covenants (which are still present, but much easier to understand and utilize), world tendencies, and navigation are a thing of the past. Dark Souls II is approachable and easy to get into, yet as difficult as ever to master. In this reviewer's opinion, the leveling system overhaul in Dark Souls II has been an extremely positive change for the series, allowing for greater player flexibility without the need to level grind, and adding consequences for those who do choose to grind. And most notably, the multiplayer features are much richer, easier to use, and much more fun in general. Multiplayer in the Souls series has always been arguably the most innovative around, offering a game within a game for those who choose to take part in it. Dark Souls II does the best job of this yet.And like I mentioned earlier, this is still a Souls game. Meaning you're going to have some of the most immersive, intense, and satisfying gameplay available anywhere. Perhaps Dark Souls II's level & world design aren't as masterful as Dark Souls'. Perhaps its enemies and bosses aren't as memorable as Demon's Souls'. That's irrelevant. Dark Souls II is a must-play game no matter what. And the best news is, that despite it perhaps not being quite as perfect as its predecessors, this is still the best place for a newcomer to the series to start. It does a fantastic job of easing the player into its world and allowing them to figure out what's going on without holding the player's hand. For that alone, this game deserves to be commended. And Dark Souls II continues to solidify what so many of us already know....that this Souls series, from developers extraordinaire From Software, is the best thing to happen to video games in a very, very long time.

When you touchpad is pressed, you can not use the keys for character input, but you can slide your finger on this area to select something on screen.Blue tooth 2.0, Short Cut Keys, and MoreDedicated short-cut keys provide time-saving instant access to Message Box and other online communication applications on the PlayStation Network. This device charges by connecting it directly to the PlayStation 3 system using a standard USB cable. It is important to note that this device features Blue tooth 2.0, with an operating range of up to 33 feet, and it comes equipped with a rechargeable Lithium-ion polymer battery (Capacity: 610mAh).By integrating all these features into a sleek and elegant design you can further enhance your online interactivity on the PlayStation 3 system.
reviewText: Well after becoming addicted to PS Home I realized it was taking far too long to have chat convos with the digital text input and I started looking for alternatives. I had a spare usb keyboard laying around but it was not compatible with my PS3. I had remembered seeing one of these keypad thingies at Wal-Mart, however no local stores seem to carry them. I cam to amazon and found one 3rd party version of it for about half the price of the Sony model so I bought it. I was not pleased with that particular item so I returned it for the much more expensive one that you're viewing right now. This thing really makes entering text a breeze and as far as it's functionality as a keyboard/text entry device I have no complaints. My gripe is with all the added features which I'm guessing they only added because they wanted more features to list on the packaging. The mouse is completely useless. I have been unsuccessful at using it since the get-go. To boot, the PS3 doesn't download a patch or anything so that you can change settings like mouse speed or sensitivity or really anything. It's just stuck at it's default and the mouse is way too sensitive, it moves when you're not even touching it and when you are the cursor acts like what happens when you try using two fingers on a touchpad for a laptop.The other place that this device is severely lacking is INSTRUCTIONS. It comes with little more instructions than a very brief piece of paper hidden in the packaging card that basically says just this; "erm... turn meh ohn den charge meh... i liek sink automatically then use me, goo sony!"I still have yet to figure out what half the buttons that aren't letters do. For some reason pressing shift does not capitalize your letters and neither does the caps lock button. Overall, for chatting where punctuation and grammar don't count for much this device is very good at what it does. It syncs to the PS3 just like a controller but I have yet to be able to check it's charge level like you would a controller. Which isn't a major thing but when you add it to all the other problems you get from this thing it leaves you wondering why in the world you ever paid so much for this thing.As far as it hooking onto the controller the mechanism is really simple, the keypad is set a little too far away and it makes entering text sorta difficult but I have small hands and short thumbs some of you guys out there with big lengthy manhands should do fine with it. I usually just leave the thing completely off the controller and I can enter text quite efficiently. The PS, START and SELECT buttons just fit over your existing ones but they work really well provided your keypad is set on the controller properly. Personally, I wouldn't buy another one of these not when you can get a full blown BT keyboard for a little more which I imagine would be quite a bit more functional than this thing.Overall it's good at what you need it for and not so good at all the added stuff or just totally useless at it anyways. I think it would be a nice idea for Sony to do a lite version of this where all it does is simple text entry with functional shift and caps lock buttons for a much lower price. But as I think this product has all but been taken off the market I doubt that will ever happen for this generation of the console. If you're frustrated with the digital text entry and don't want to drop the 80+ bucks on a PS3 keyboard then I would suggest this over any other piece of equipment. If you're used to QWERTY text messaging you will have no problems using this device. For more frugal shoppers I suggest the 3rd party model which is a lot cheaper but doesn't look or fit as good on your controller.
